Award.AwardTitle: NetSE: Small: Structure and Dynamics of Complex Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Social Web, or Web 2.0, has changed the way people connect with each other and use information. Sites such as Twitter, Flickr, and Digg allow people to create content, annotate it with descriptive labels, and befriend others to create communities. The collective knowledge and expertise of the community is expressed through the links between people and information. The key to extracting this knowledge is understanding the structure and dynamics of networks.

This project will study dynamics of information spread on networks and how it relates to network structure and quality of information. In previous work, investigator has developed a mathematical framework to study the properties of static networks. She showed that a centrality metric based on the number of paths connecting nodes can be used to identify groups and important nodes within them. However, looking at static structure ignores valuable temporal information that can be used to improve the ability to identify influential nodes and hidden groups, as well as quickly and reliably predict important trends and evaluate the quality of information. The investigator will extend these metrics to dynamic networks and model information spread on networks. The investigator will apply these methods to complex networks that link different types of entities, namely, people, content, and groups.

Considering network structure in the dynamics of information spread will lead to more effective tools to leverage community's knowledge to address a number of problems, including identifying important trends, assessing information quality, and separating true information from rumors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The rapid growth of online social networking sites, such as Twitter and Facebook, has renewed interest in network analysis methods which can identify central, or influential, social media users, uncover communities of like-minded users, and suggest new people or content to follow. Traditionally, network analysis has considered only the edges between network nodes, i.e., network topology. Researchers from University of Southern California Information Sciences Institute (USC/ISI), however, showed that network structure is the product of both its topology and the flows taking place on the network. These flows, which are mediated by interactions between nodes, determine the phenomena taking place on the network, whether diffusion and other types of transport in biological networks, or the spread of a disease in social networks. 

Social scientists have proposed a variety of measures to identify important, or central, individuals in social networks. Such individuals are, for example, those who control the flow of information on a network. The figure illustrates the impact of flows on centrality. The figure shows long-term evolution of two different flows on the network: (a) diffusion, which can be modeled as a random walk in which the flow transitions to a single neighbor or a current node, and (b) an epidemic process, which can transition to multiple neighbors. Larger nodes, are visited by the flow more often, hence, they have greater control over the flow and are more central. Clearly, different flows produce different notions of centrality. In addition to centrality, USC/ISI researchers have also elucidated the relationship between flows and community structure.

Social interactions on social media, however, cannot be modeled as random walks nor epidemics. USC/ISI researchers showed that a social media users' capacity to receive an incoming message is limited by their finite attention, which they divide over all incoming messages from the friends they follow. They have proposed new measures of centrality that model the effect of divided attention on the random walk and epidemic processes respectively. They have evaluated different centrality measures on real-world online social networks and showed that the measure that takes into account the limited attention, broadcast-based interactions in social media best predicts influential users in social media.

Broader impacts: This project has led researchers to rethink network analysis, and produced new measures for network analysis. Material from this research was integrated into new course on Social Media Analysis at USC and many publication and presentations at leading Computer Science and Social Science conferences.
